description.en: The course concists reading and discussing essential texts in environmental humanities. The course rises the competence of the participiants on environemntal problems, their social and cultural aspects. The cource presumes individual reading of selected thematic texts (mostly short monographs) in 400-600 pages in total. The seminars presume active participation and shared discusssion.
description.et: Kursuse sisuks on oluliste keskkonnahumanitaaria tekstide lugemine ja ühisarutelu. Kursus tõstab osalejate teadlikust keskkonnaprobleemide, nende sotsiaalsete ja kultuuriliste tahkude osas. Kursuse raames loetakse valitud temaatilisi tekste (peamiselt lühimonograafiaid) kogumahus 400-600 lk. Seminarid eeldavad aktiivset osalust ja ühisarutelu.

objectives.en: The aim of the course is to achieve knowledge on environmental crisis, its cultural causes and effects and mitication by discussing essential texts in environmental humanities.
objectives.et: Õppeaine eesmärgiks on teadmiste omandamine keskkonnakriisi, selle kultuuriliste põhjuste, mõjude ning leevendusvõimaluste kohta arutledes keskkonnahumanitaaria oluliste tekstide üle.

learning_outcomes.en: -	orients well in enironmental humanities discourse;
-	knows cultural causes and effects of environmental crices;
learning_outcomes.et: -	tunneb keskkonnakriisi kultuurilisi põhjuseid ja mõjusid;

learning_outcomes.en: -	is well informed on the recent developments of the environmental crices and mitigation measures
learning_outcomes.et: -	on hästi informeeritud keskkonnakriisi tänastest arengutest ja leevendusvõimalustest.

description.et:
For the seminar we read and discuss following texts:
O’Gorman, Emily et al. 2019. Teaching the Environmental Humanities: International Perspectives and Practices. Environmental Humanities 11 (2): 427–460.
Saari, Antti & John Mullen 2020. Dark places: environmental education research in a world of hyperobjects, Environmental Education Research, 26:9-10, 1466-1478.
Affifi, Ramsey; Hensley, Nathan Stewart 2024. Trickster Teaching and The Anthropocene: Disrupting The Explicitification of Pedagogy, People And Planet. Environmental Education Research, 1–18. 
Gärdebo, Johan; Helsing, Daniel; Svensson, Anna; Brenthel, Adam 2014. We Don’t Need No Education: A Case Study for Situating the Environmental Humanities. Resilience: A Journal of the Environmental Humanities 1(3): 42-53

For the seminar we read and discuss following texts:
Nixon, Rob 2011. Slow Violence And The Environmentalism Of The Poor. MA: Harvard University Press. INTODUCTION and CHAPTERS 1, 2 (pp. 1-102).
Ahmann, Chloe 2018. “It's Exhausting to Create An Event Out Of Nothing”: Slow Violence And The Manipulation Of Time. Cultural Anthropology, 33(1), 142–171.
Davies, Thom 2022. Slow Violence and Toxic Geographies: ‘Out Of Sight’ To Whom? Environment and Planning C: Politics and Space, 40(2), 409-427.

For the seminar we read and discuss following texts:
Barad, Karen 2003. Posthumanist Performativity: Toward an Understanding of How Matter Comes to Matter. Signs, 28(3), 801–831. 
Elton, Sarah 2021. Growing Methods: Developing a Methodology for Identifying Plant Agency and Vegetal Politics in the City. Environmental Humanities, 13(1): 93–112.
Wadham, Helen 2021. Relations of Power and Nonhuman Agency: Critical Theory, Clever Hans, and Other Stories of Horses and Humans. Sociological Perspectives, 64(1), 109-126.

For the seminar we read and discuss following texts:
Plumwood, Val 1993. Feminism and the Mastery of Nature. London: Routledge. (INTRODUCTION + CHAPTER 1 FEMINISM AND ECOFEMINISM, Pp 1-40).
Braidotti, Rosi 2017. Four Theses on Posthuman Feminism. In; R Grusin (ed.), Anthropocene Feminism. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, pp. 21-48.
Hamilton, Jennifer Mae; Neimanis Astrida 2018. Composting Feminisms and Environmental Humanities. Environmental Humanities 10(2): 501–527.
